div1.p: Moran discusses his revision of Hench's interview transcript.

div1.head: Letter from John J. Moran to Philip Showalter Hench, April 23, 1940
div1.opener:
Havana, April 23, 1940.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
MAYO CLINIC,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am sending you herewith a revised copy of the question-
naire you had prepared for me and the answers to which were dictated to
Mrs. Phillips. I have made no change of an essential nature in your
questions and such changes as I have made in them are purely aimed at
interpreting what you had in mind when you formulated them.

On the other hand, I have enlarged upon or clarified my
own answers so that the uninitiated can make sense out of them and dove-
tail my statements with names, places and dates. All my life, I have
been a “crank” on details. My “Sick & Wounded” reports, while in the
Hospital Corps of the Army here, were considered models in that diagnosis,
a matter of prime importance for the office of the Surgeon General of
the Army, had to be complete to the minutest detail and written, in long
hand, within a very limited space. If it concerned an “incised wound” on
the index or other finger of the left or right hand, the exact location
had to be anatomically stated and a disease had to be described as acute
or chronic, etc., etc. The doctors responsible for diagnosis considered
me more or less of a nuisance because of my insistence that diagnosis
should be complete. There was method in my madness. If the “Sick &
Wounded Report” got by the Chief Surgeon's Office, showing an incomplete
diagnosis, it was sure to be discovered in the Surgeon General's Office
and request made for its completion, to the Post of origin, through
regular military channels. Those prepared by me were considered models
for neatness, legibility and completeness by the Chief Surgeon of my
Department. Now, I will proceed.

Certain incidents in the life of every one of us stick out
like a sore thumb, as do important dates. They remain engraved in our
memories. I do not claim infallibility in connection with certain months
mentioned in this questionnaire but those of paramount importance are
still fresh in my memory. What happened is still fresh in my memory.
For instance, I have mentioned 4:30 P. M. as the hour when I was accosted
by Dr. Ames while on my way to my room within the Post Hospital grounds,
after finishing my day's work at General Lee's Headquarters, while the
hour may have been 5:30 just as well. Kissinger and I may have arrived
at the “momentous decision” at 1, 2 or 3 o'clock in the morning. The
exact hour had no special meaning for me as I had made my own decision
before I discussed it with him. I think you can see what I am driving at.
I hope so, at least.

It has been no small task to write out the six pages enclosed
with two index fingers, as you can well imagine and I do hope that you will
not feel dissatisfied with the revised product. Will get all the other
pending items assembled as soon as possible and forward same to you with
least possible delay. With very kindest regards to Mrs. Hench and your
good self, from in which Elida joins me, I remain,
